headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Paul Mountain, Director
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Paul Mountain, Director of Investor Relations. Thank you sir, you may begin.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christine. I'd like to thank everyone for participating in this conference call and webcast to review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings, recent developments and operating performance.Our speakers today will be our Chairman and CE
componenttext:
Thank you, Christine. I'd like to thank everyone for participating in this conference call and webcast to review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings, recent developments and operating performance.
Our speakers today will be our Chairman and CEO, Don Brandt; and our CFO, Jim Hatfield. Jeff Guldner, APS's Senior Vice President of Public Policy; and Mark Schiavoni, APS's Chief Operating Officer, are also here with us.
First, I need to cover a few details with you. The slides that we'll be using are available on our Investor Relations website, along with our earnings release and related information. Note that the slides contain reconciliations of certain non-GAAP financial information.
Today's comments in our slides contains forward-looking statements based on current expectations, and the company assumes no obligation to update these statements. Because actual results may differ materially from expectations, we caution you not to place undue reliance on these statements.
Our 2015 Form 10-K was filed this morning. Please refer to that document for forward-looking statements, cautionary language as well as the risk factors in MD&A sections, which identify risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in our disclosures.
A replay of this call will be available shortly on our website for the next 30 days. It will also be available by telephone through February 26.
I will now turn the call over to Don.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul, and thank you, all, for joining us today. Pinnacle West delivered a solid 2015 with earnings near to high end of our guidance range with Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station having a record year, and with the balance sheet that remains one
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul, and thank you, all, for joining us today. Pinnacle West delivered a solid 2015 with earnings near to high end of our guidance range with Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station having a record year, and with the balance sheet that remains one of the strongest in the industry. Jim will discuss the financial results and outlook, will focus mostly on the year ahead.
Our fleet performed very well in 2015, highlighted by Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Stations, high output every equating to a capacity factor of 94.3%. One of Palo Verde's key strengths is the ability of the team to perform at an excellent level, but also to drive continuous improvement in each year.
2016 marks the beginning of a new period for our feet. In total, we're planning to invest over $3.6 billion in capital over the next 3 years. We're investing in 2 large projects in our fossil fleet as well as a few innovative investments and some IT systems to prepare our operations for the long term. The 2 large fossil projects are the modernization project, and the selective catalytic reduction pollution controls or SCR, as they call at the Four Corners Generating Plant.
Four Corners Units 5 entered a major outage in January to make several upgrades, and begin laying the groundwork for the SCR installations. The innovative investments, I will outline, are designed to increase customers and system reliability, and meet future resource needs. In November, we announced a partnership with the Department of The Navy to develop a 25 megawatts project at Marine Air Station, Newmont. This is APS's first micro braid project in the first military base to secure 100% backup power.
We also plan to install a 40-megawatt solar facility this year on behalf of some of our larger customers. This amount has been reflected in our 2016 CapEx budget.
The Solar Partner program, which is planned for 1500 APS-owned rooftop solar installations, is on track to be fully installed and operational by mid-2016. And just this month, we officially launched our solar innovation study, a 75 demand rate laboratory, here in the Metro Phoenix area, which will determine how customers can use various combinations of distributed energy, resources such as solar panels, battery storage, smart and high efficiency HVAC systems to better manage their energy environments. These customers will also be placed on our existing residential demand rate, and the study will provide valuable information on customer's ability to use technology to manage the peak demand and lower their bills.
In addition to generation investments, we're upgrading several IT systems to improve our customer interface, facilitate operation of our transmission and distribution systems, and enable participation in the California ISO energy in balance market.
These investments along with our advanced meter programs, which is fully deployed, are enabling integration of the technology, while also allowing us to maintain stability.
2016 also represents an important year under regulatory calendar with the APS rate case said to be filed on June 1. APS submitted the notice of intent to file on January 29, which gives notice to the ACC and stakeholders, and outlines a primary topics, we will propose in June rate filing.
APS will propose the new rates going into effect in July 1, 2017, based on the test year-ended December 31, 2015 with certain adjustments.
To help achieve this outcome, we have held a series of stakeholder meetings to provide clarity and transparency with the stakeholders.
We're also planning to submit an extensive list of standard discovery questions and responses with the June 1st filing.
Let me outline a few of the central topics from the notice of intent to filing. Residential rate design is an area where we will propose changes to better align cost with prices and incentivize cost-reducing technologies. And we will be proposing universal demand rate, as well as shifting our time of used periods to later in the day. We will also propose a revenue per customer decoupling mechanism that will be adjusted annually to replace the existing laws fixed-cost recover mechanism. That decoupling mechanism will be proposed on a trial basis until the next rate case to act as a rate stabilizing mechanism during the transition period to the new rates structure.
The last item, I'll mention is, we'll request the deferral of cost related to 2 large CapEx projects, we're investing in, the SCR's at Four Corners, and the first ramping natural gas modernization project at. These investments total over $900 million over the next few years, within service states of 2018 and 2019, respectively.
And in the case of the SCR's, since the timing of the installations, will be close to the end of this rate case, we'll also propose a step mechanism to reflect the deferred SCR cost similar to the treatment of the Four Corners acquisition.
The on value and cost of distributed generation has testimony due on February 25. There also 4 other electric rate cases in process. UNS electric is the first in line with hearings set to begin on March 1 in. We are an active intervenor in the UNS case since it is an important forum to discuss rate design. The testimony we filed supports the concept of 3-part rate design, which incorporates a fixed service charge and energy charge and the demand charge. This concept was also proposed and supported by UNS electric and the ACC staff.
Related topics including methodologies for determining the cost to serve customers with solar and the value of solar will be a central focus in the value and cost of distributed generation docket.
In closing, we delivered on our commitments in 2015. And we are well positioned for 2016 in the long-term with a clear plan on the strong leadership team in place to deliver on the plan.
I'll now turn the call over to Jim.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don, and thank you, everyone, for joining us on the call. This morning, we reported our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. As you can see, on Slide 3 of the materials, we had a solid year and ended on a strong note. Be
componenttext:
Thank you, Don, and thank you, everyone, for joining us on the call. This morning, we reported our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. As you can see, on Slide 3 of the materials, we had a solid year and ended on a strong note. Before I review the details of our 2015 results, let me touch on a few highlights from the quarter.
For the fourth quarter of 2015, we earned $0.37 per share, compared to $0.05 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014.
Slide 4 outlines the variances, which drove the increase in our quarterly earnings per share. Looking at gross margin, higher retail sales, favorable weather and the assessment mechanism were all positive contributors. Also, as we anticipated, lower operational and maintenance in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to 2014 improved earnings largely due to lower plant averages.
Now turning to Slide 5, let's review some of the details of our full year results. We delivered positive results in the top 10 of our guidance range, earning $3.92 per share compared to $3.58 per share in 2014, and consolidated ROU of 9.77%, which was in line with our goal of achieving more the 9.5%.
Gross margin was a positive driver for the year, including favorable year-over-year weather. The adjustment mechanisms were also earning accretive in 2015 including the lost fixed cost recovery revenue, transmission and our Arizona program. The Four Corners that went into effect in January 1, 2015, was the largest driver in gross margin, however, keep in mind that the Four Corners was was largely offset in D&A.
by APS customers in 2015 versus 2014 contributed to earnings. Weather normalized retail kilowatt hour sales after taxes energy efficiency, customer behavior and distributed generation were up 1%, year-over-year.
2015 was our strongest year for retail sales growth since 2008, including 3 of our Four Corners, in which combined customers and usage growth outweighed the impact of energy efficiency and distributed generation.
Operations and maintenance was lower in 2015 compared to 2014 due in part due our ongoing cost management efforts. The largest reductions include a decrease in employee benefit cost, and the lower cost related to fossil plant averages.
Lower interest expense net of was another benefit to earnings to 2015, compared to 2014. The decrease included reduce charges resulting from refinancing long-term debt and lower rates, and higher construction working progress balances, benefiting.
Higher depreciation and amortization expense was a primary headwind to 2015 earnings as compared to 2014.
As we reported all year, higher D&A decreased earnings due impart to the absence of the 2014 Four Corners cost, and related 2015 amortization of the deferrals in the cost associated with the Four Corners acquisition in 2013. Additional planting service also reduced year-over-year earnings.
Because Arizona is common part of our business story, let me highlight few of the trends we are seeing in our local economy, in particular, the Metro Phoenix area.
By and large, when we see on Slide 6, is the continuation of the consistent growth trends we've been describing for you the last couple of years. Job growth in the fourth quarter in the Metro Phoenix area remained above the national average, as it has for the past 18 quarters. As seen on the upper panel, Metro Phoenix added jobs at a 2.8% year-over-year rate. This job growth is broad-based with the construction, healthcare, tourism, financial, business sectors, Consumer Services sectors, each adding jobs at a rate about 3%. Notably, the construction sector, at when adding jobs in the last 2 quarters at a rate of about 7%, growth in consumer Phoenix is robust, and as the market strengthened.
Our expectation for the Metro Phoenix can be seen on the lower panel.
In 2015, the housing market recorded it's best year since 2007, from both total permits and has been family sector, by itself, with almost 22,000 permits and 15,000 respectively.  This level of single-family permit activity represents an increase over the prior year of almost 50%. As you can see on the slide, we expect to have the market to improve in 2016 with total housing permits within the range of 25,000 to 32,000.
In summary, the Metro Phoenix economy continues to grow steadily and is positioned for stronger growth in the next couple of years.
As I mentioned before, Arizona and the Metro Phoenix remains attractive places to lives and do business, especially as it is situated relative to the high-cost California market. 2015 was better than 2014 in terms of job growth, income growth, consumer spending and new construction and we expect to see 2016 to be better than 2015.
Reflecting the steady improvement in the economic conditions, APS's retain customer base grew 1.3%, compared with the fourth quarter last year and 1.2% year-over-year. We expect that this growth rate will gradually accelerate in response to the economic growth trends I just discussed. Importantly, the long-term fundamentals supporting future population, job growth, and the economic development in Arizona appeared to be in place.
Now, I'll review our earnings guidance and financial outlook.
Last quarter, we issued Pinnacle West consolidated ongoing earnings for 2016, which we continue to expect to be the range of $3.90 to $4.10 per share.
The adjusted mechanism, particularly transmission and the LFCR, along with modest sales growth in normal weather remained the key gross margin drivers. O&M is above trend in 2016. However, non-outage O&M spend remains flat. As you may recall, last year, we reported that we have moved a plant Four Corners unit from 2015 to 2016. 2016 includes major planned of both Four Corners and. The planned 82-day major Four Corners Units 5 started in January, which creates a Q1 2016 earnings headwind of about $0.13 quarter-over-quarter. Keep in mind, this was factored into our guidance.
Overall,, our focus remains on our cost management efforts as we look through 2016 and beyond, but the averages are our priority for us this year. One other comment on O&M, the status of our pension plans remains strong at 88%, as of year-end 2015. The continued implementation of our liability driven Investment Strategy has helped us keep cost down. There is a slide in the appendix, which additional details on our pension plan.
You will find a complete list of factors and assumptions underlying our guidance in the Phoenix to slides which are unchanged.
As Don mentioned, our balance sheet remains strong. I will outline our financial plan and how the impact of bonus depreciation has factored in. We have already assumed a two-year bonus depreciation and that was incorporated to our rate basis closure in the last earnings call. Our updated estimates can be found in the appendix, which show an incremental reduction in rate base of approximately $200 million in 2018 as a result of the depreciation.
However, the extension also resulted in approximately $550 million of total cash benefit through 2019, which provides financing flexibility over that time horizon. In terms of capital expenditures, we anticipate APS's spend average around $1.2 billion annually from 2016 to 2018, which will be primarily funded through internally generated cash flow. With this capital spending level taking into account the depreciation, we continue to expect our rate base to grow at average annual rate of 6% to 7% through 2018.
Turning to 2016 financing, we planned to refinance a $250 million maturity in August, and anticipate additional long-term debt. Overall, the quarter remains very strong. At the end of 2015, neither Pinnacle West or APS had any short-term debt outstanding.
In summary, given the strength of our balance sheet, coupled with the extensive of bonus depreciation, we no longer forecast the need for additional equity. The net effect of bonus depreciation and the removal of equity leads a relatively new from earnings perspective.
We will continue to review our capital forecast to identify additional investment opportunities as we move forward.
This concludes our prepared remarks. I'll now turn the call back over to the operator for questions.

componenttext: We've made a fair number of changes, earlier, last probably 2 or 3 rate cases that have picked that up. A lot of that comes in the process the case, and trying to get that processing time down to a year or so, and things we've done with that, are for example, prefiling the discovery. So we don't wait, file a case, wait for 3, 4 months, and then begin the discovery process. And so a lot of that's been worked out, obviously adjustor mechanisms and how you can work on adjustment mechanisms, can help smooth that even further. And so that's probably going to be some of the discussion you'll see and that part of what we've been talking about with stakeholders.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Paul Mountain, Director
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Paul Mountain, Director of Investor Relations. Thank you, sir. You may begin.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christine.I'd like to thank everyone for participating in this conference call and webcast to review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings, recent developments and operating performance.Our speakers today will be our Chairman and C
componenttext:
Thank you, Christine.
I'd like to thank everyone for participating in this conference call and webcast to review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings, recent developments and operating performance.
Our speakers today will be our Chairman and CEO, Don Brandt; and our CFO, Jim Hatfield. Jeff Guldner, APS's Senior Vice President of Public Policy; and Mark Schiavoni, APS's Chief Operating Officer, are also here with us.
First, I need to cover a few details with you. The slides that we will be using are available on our Investor Relations website, along with our earnings release and related information. Note that the slides contain reconciliations of certain non-GAAP financial information.
Today's comments in our slides contains forward-looking statements based on current expectations, and the company assumes no obligation to update these statements. Because actual results may differ materially from expectations, we caution you not to place undue reliance on these statements.
Our 2015 Form 10-K was filed this morning. Please refer to that document for forward-looking statements, cautionary language as well as the risk factors in MD&A sections, which identify risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in our disclosures.
A replay of this call will be available shortly on our website for the next 30 days. It will also be available by telephone through February 26.
I will now turn the call over to Don.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul, and thank you all for joining us today.Pinnacle West delivered a solid 2015 with earnings near the high end of our guidance range with Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station having a record year and with the balance sheet that remains one o
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul, and thank you all for joining us today.
Pinnacle West delivered a solid 2015 with earnings near the high end of our guidance range with Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station having a record year and with the balance sheet that remains one of the strongest in the industry. Jim will discuss the financial results and outlook. My comments will focus mostly on the year ahead.
Our fleet performed very well in 2015, highlighted by Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Stations highest output every, equating to a capacity factor of 94.3%. One of Palo Verde's key strengths is the ability of the team to perform at an excellent level but to also drive continuous improvement in each year.
2016 marks the beginning of a new period for our feet. In total, we are planning to invest over $3.6 billion in capital over the next 3 years. We're investing in 2 large projects in our fossil fleet as well as a few innovative investments and some IT systems to prepare our operations for the long term. The 2 large fossil projects are the Ocotillo Modernization Project and the selective catalytic reduction pollution controls, or SCR as they're called, at the Four Corners generating plant.
Four Corners Unit 5 entered a major outage in January to make several upgrades and begin laying the groundwork for the SCR installations. The innovative investments I will outline are designed to increase customer and system reliability and meet future resource needs. In November, we announced the partnership with the Department of The Navy to develop a 25-megawatt microgrid project at Marine Corps Air Station Yuma. This is APS's first microgrid project in the first military base to secure 100% backup power.
We also plan to install a 40-megawatt solar facility this year on behalf of some of our larger customers. This amount has been reflected in our 2016 CapEx budget.
The Solar Partner Program, which is planned for 1500 APS-owned rooftop solar installations, is on track to be fully installed and operational by mid-2016. And just this month, we officially launched our solar innovation study, a 75-home demand rate laboratory here in the Metro Phoenix area, which will determine how customers can use various combinations of distributed energy resources such as solar panels, battery storage, smart thermostats and high-efficiency HVAC systems to better manage their energy environments. These customers will also be placed on our existing residential demand rate, and the study will provide valuable information on a customer's ability to use technology to manage the peak demand and lower their bills.
In addition to generation investments, we're upgrading several IT systems to improve our customer interface, facilitate active operation of our transmission and distribution systems and enable participation in the California ISO - Energy Imbalance Market. These investments along with our advanced meter program, which is fully deployed, are enabling integration of advanced technologies while also allowing us to maintain grid stability.
2016 also represents an important year on the regulatory calendar with the APS rate case set to be filed on June 1. APS submitted the notice of intent to file on January 29, which gives notice to the ACC and stakeholders and outlines primary topics we will propose in the June rate filing. APS will propose the new rates go into effect July 1, 2017, based on the test year ended December 31, 2015, with certain adjustments.
To help achieve this outcome, we have held a series of stakeholder meetings to provide clarity and transparency with the stakeholders. We're also planning to submit an extensive list of standard discovery questions and responses with the June 1st filing.
Let me outline a few of the central topics from the notice of intent to filing. Residential rate design is an area where we will propose changes to better align costs with prices and incentivize cost-reducing technologies. And we will be proposing universal demand rates as well as shifting our time of use periods to later in the day. We will also propose a revenue per customer decoupling mechanism that will be adjusted annually to replace the existing lost fixed-cost recovery mechanism. The decoupling mechanism will be proposed on a trial basis until the next rate case to act as a rate-stabilizing mechanism during the transition period to the new rate structure.
The last item I'll mention is we will request the deferral of costs related to 2 large CapEx projects we're investing in the SCs -- excuse me, SCRs at Four Corners and the first ramping natural gas modernization project at Ocotillo. These investments total over $900 million over the next few years, with in-service dates of 2018 and 2019, respectively.
And in the case of the SCRs, since the timing of installations will be close to the end of this rate case, we'll also propose a step mechanism to reflect the deferred SCR cost similar to the treatment of the Four Corners acquisition.
The docket on value and cost of distributed generation has testimony due on February 25. There also 4 other electric rate cases in process. UNS Electric is the first in line with hearings set to begin on March 1 in Tucson. We are an active intervenor in the UNS case since it is an important forum to discuss rate design. The testimony we filed supports the concept of 3-part rate design, which incorporates a fixed service charge and energy charge and a demand charge. This concept was also proposed and supported by UNS Electric and the ACC staff. Related topics including methodologies for determining the cost to serve customers with solar and the value of solar will be a central focus in the value and cost of distributed generation docket.
In closing, we delivered on our commitments in 2015. And we are well-positioned for 2016 in the long-term, with a clear plan and a strong leadership team in place to deliver on the plan.
I'll now turn the call over to Jim.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don, and thank you, everyone, for joining us on the call.This morning, we reported our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. As you can see on Slide 3 of the materials, we had a solid year and ended on a strong note.B
componenttext:
Thank you, Don, and thank you, everyone, for joining us on the call.
This morning, we reported our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. As you can see on Slide 3 of the materials, we had a solid year and ended on a strong note.
Before I review the details of our 2015 results, let me touch on a few highlights from the quarter. For the fourth quarter of 2015, we earned $0.37 per share, compared to $0.05 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014.
Slide 4 outlines the variances which drove the increase in our quarterly earnings per share. Looking at gross margin, higher retail sales, favorable weather and the adjustment mechanism were all positive contributors. Also, as we anticipated, lower operations in maintenance business in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to 2014 improved earnings largely due to lower planned fossil outages.
Now turning to Slide 5, let's review some of the details of our full year results. We delivered positive results in the top 10 of our guidance range, earning $3.92 per share compared to $3.58 per share in 2014, and [indiscernible] a consolidated ROE of 9.77%, which was in line with our goal of achieving more the 9.5%.
Gross margin was a positive driver for the year, including favorable year-over-year weather. The adjustment mechanisms were also earnings accretive in 2015, including the lost fixed cost recovery mechanism, transmission and our AZ Sun Program. The Four Corners rate change that went into effect on January 1, 2015, was the largest driver in gross margin. However, keep in mind that the Four Corners rate change was largely offset in D&A.
Power usage by APS customers in 2015 versus 2014 contributed to earnings. Weather normalized, retail kilowatt hour sales, updated effects of energy efficiency, customer behavior and distributed generation were up 7/10 to 1%, year-over-year.
2015 was our strongest year for retail sales growth since 2008, including 3 on Four Corners, in which combined customer and usage growth outweighed the impacts of energy efficiency and distributed generation.
Operations and maintenance expense was lower in 2015 compared to 2014 due in part to our ongoing cost management efforts. The largest reductions include a decrease in employee benefit costs and lower costs related to fossil plant outages.
Lower interest expense net of AFUDC was another benefit to earnings in 2015 compared to 2014. The decrease included reduce charges resulting from refinancing long-term debt and a lower rate and higher construction in work-in-progress balances, benefiting AFUDC.
Higher depreciation and amortization expense was the primary headwind to 2015 earnings as compared to 2014.
As we reported all year, higher D&A decreased earnings due in part to the absence of the 2014 Four Corners cost deferrals and related 2015 amortization of the deferrals in the costs associated with the Four Corners acquisition in 2013. Additional planting service also reduced year-over-year earnings.
Because Arizona is [indiscernible] commonly as an integral part of our business story, let me highlight to you the trends we are seeing in our local economy and in particular, the Metro Phoenix area.
By and large, what you see on Slide 6 is the continuation of the consistent growth trends we have been describing for you the last couple of years. Job growth in the fourth quarter in the Metro Phoenix area remained above the national average as it has for the past 18 quarters. As seen on the upper panel, Metro Phoenix added jobs at a 2.8% year-over-year rate. This job growth is broad-based with the construction, healthcare, tourism, financial, business sectors, consumer services sectors each adding jobs at a rate above 3%. Notably, the construction sector has been adding jobs in the last 2 quarters at a rate of above 7%. Growth in consumer spending remains robust, and the healthy market continues to strengthen.
Our expectation for the Metro Phoenix housing permits can be seen on the lower panel. In 2015, the housing market recorded it's best year since 2007, from both total permits and the single-family sector by itself, with almost 22,000 permits and 15,000 permits, respectively. This level of single-family permit activity represents an increase over the prior year of almost 50%. As you can see on the slide, we expect the housing market to improve in 2016, with total housing permits within a range of 25,000 to 32,000.
In summary, the Metro Phoenix economy continues to grow steadily and is positioned for stronger growth in the next couple of years.
As I had mentioned before, Arizona and the Metro Phoenix remain attractive places to live and do business, especially as it is situated relative to the high-cost California market. 2015 was better than 2014 in terms of job growth, income growth, consumer spending and new construction, and we expect to see 2016 to be better than 2015.
Reflecting the steady improvement in economic conditions, APS's retain customer base grew 1.3%, compared with the fourth quarter last year and 1.2% year-over-year. We expect that this growth rate will gradually accelerate in response to the economic growth trends I just discussed. Importantly, the long-term fundamentals supporting future population, job growth and economic development in Arizona appear to be in place.
Now, I'll review our earnings guidance and financial outlook.
Last quarter, we issued Pinnacle West consolidated ongoing earnings for 2016, which we continue to expect to be the range of $3.90 to $4.10 per share. The adjusted mechanism, particularly transmission and the LFCR along with modest sales growth and normal weather, remained the key gross margin drivers. O&M is above trend in 2016. However, non-outage O&M spend remains flat. As you may recall, last year we reported that we had moved a planned Four Corners unit outage from 2015 to 2016. 2016 includes major planned outages of both Four Corners and Toya [ph]. The planned 82-day major overhaul at Four Corners Unit 5 started in January, which creates a Q1 2016 earnings headwind of about $0.13 quarter-over-quarter. Keep in mind, this was factored into our guidance.
Overall,, our focus remains on our cost management efforts as we look through 2016 and beyond, but the outages are a priority for us this year. One other comment on O&M, the funded status of our pension plan remains strong at 88%, as of year-end 2015. The continued implementation of our liability-driven investment strategy has helped us keep costs down. There is a slide in the appendix with additional details on our pension plan.
You'll find a complete list of factors and assumptions underlying our guidance in the appendix to our slides which are unchanged.
As Don mentioned, our balance sheet remains strong. I will outline our financial plan and how the impact of bonus depreciation has factored in. We had already assumed a two-year extension of bonus depreciation that was incorporated to our rate base disclosures in the last earnings call. Our updated estimates can be found in the appendix would show an incremental reduction in rate base of approximately $200 million in 2018 as a result of the bonus depreciation.
However, the extension also resulted in approximately $550 million of total cash benefits to 2019, which provides financing flexibility over that time horizon. In terms of capital expenditures, we anticipate APS's spend to average around $1.2 billion annually from 2016 to 2018, which will be primarily funded through internally generated cash flow. With this capital spending level taking into account the bonus depreciation, we continue to expect our rate base to grow at a average annual rate of 6% to 7% through 2018.
Turning to 2016 financing, we plan to refinance the $250-million maturity in August and anticipate issuance of [indiscernible] of additional long-term debt. Overall, the quarter remains very strong. At the end of 2015, neither Pinnacle West nor APS had any short-term debt outstanding.
In summary, given the strength of our balance sheet coupled with the extension of bonus depreciation, we no longer forecast the need for additional equity. The net effect of bonus depreciation and the removal of equity leaves us relatively neutral from an earnings perspective. We will continue to review our capital forecast to identify additional investment opportunities as we move forward.
This concludes our prepared remarks. I'll now turn the call back over to the operator for questions.

componenttext: Sure. Dan, so there was a extensive discussion in Arizona a few years ago around decoupling mechanisms in general. In our last rate case, we had proposed that LFCR mechanism as a essentially from the settlement process. But the way a revenue-per-customer mechanism would work is it takes into account all of the different adjustments, so whether sales as well as just other changes to -- essentially changes to the normal revenue requirement process. But what it does is it looks at it to accommodate customer growth, right? So it's customers growing or making additional investments into the system. We need to be able to pickup the additional cost that comes from that growth. Does that make sense?

componenttext: We've made a fair number of changes earlier last, probably 2 or 3 rate cases that have picked that up. A lot of it comes in the time to process the case and trying to get that processing time down to about a year or so, and things we've done with that are, for example, prefiling the discovery. So we don't wait -- file the case, wait for 3 or 4 months and then begin the discovery process. And so a lot of that's been worked out. Obviously, adjustor mechanisms and how you can work on adjustment mechanisms can help smooth that even further. And so that's probably going to be some of the discussion you'll see, and that's part of what we've been talking about with stakeholders.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Paul Mountain, Director
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Paul Mountain, Director of Investor Relations. Thank you, sir. You may begin.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christine.I'd like to thank everyone for participating in this conference call and webcast to review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings, recent developments and operating performance.Our speakers today will be our Chairman and C
componenttext:
Thank you, Christine.
I'd like to thank everyone for participating in this conference call and webcast to review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings, recent developments and operating performance.
Our speakers today will be our Chairman and CEO, Don Brandt; and our CFO, Jim Hatfield. Jeff Guldner, APS's Senior Vice President of Public Policy; and Mark Schiavoni, APS's Chief Operating Officer, are also here with us.
First, I need to cover a few details with you. The slides that we will be using are available on our Investor Relations website, along with our earnings release and related information. Note that the slides contain reconciliations of certain non-GAAP financial information.
Today's comments on our slides contain forward-looking statements based on current expectations, and the company assumes no obligation to update these statements. Because actual results may differ materially from expectations, we caution you not to place undue reliance on these statements.
Our 2015 Form 10-K was filed this morning. Please refer to that document for forward-looking statements, cautionary language as well as the risk factors in MD&A sections, which identify risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in our disclosures.
A replay of this call will be available shortly on our website for the next 30 days. It will also be available by telephone through February 26.
I will now turn the call over to Don.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul, and thank you all for joining us today.Pinnacle West delivered a solid 2015 with earnings near the high end of our guidance range with Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station having a record year and with the balance sheet that remains one o
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul, and thank you all for joining us today.
Pinnacle West delivered a solid 2015 with earnings near the high end of our guidance range with Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station having a record year and with the balance sheet that remains one of the strongest in the industry. Jim will discuss the financial results and outlook. My comments will focus mostly on the year ahead.
Our fleet performed very well in 2015, highlighted by Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Stations highest output every, equating to a capacity factor of 94.3%. One of Palo Verde's key strengths is the ability of the team to perform at an excellent level but to also drive continuous improvement in each year.
2016 marks the beginning of a new period for our fleet. In total, we are planning to invest over $3.6 billion in capital over the next 3 years. We're investing in 2 large projects in our fossil fleet, as well as a few innovative investments and some IT systems to prepare our operations for the long term. The 2 large fossil projects are the Ocotillo Modernization Project and the selective catalytic reduction pollution controls, or SCRs as they're called, at the Four Corners generating plant.
Four Corners Unit 5 entered a major outage in January to make several upgrades and begin laying the groundwork for the SCR installations. The innovative investments I will outline are designed to increase customer and system reliability and meet future resource needs. In November, we announced the partnership with the Department of The Navy to develop a 25-megawatt microgrid project at Marine Corps Air Station Yuma. This is APS's first microgrid project, and the first military base to secure 100% backup power.
We also plan to install a 40-megawatt solar facility this year on behalf of some of our larger customers. This amount has been reflected in our 2016 CapEx budget.
The Solar Partner Program, which is planned for 1500 APS-owned rooftop solar installations, is on track to be fully installed and operational by mid-2016. And just this month, we officially launched our solar innovation study, a 75-home demand rate laboratory here in the Metro Phoenix area, which will determine how customers can use various combinations of distributed energy resources such as solar panels, battery storage, smart thermostats and high-efficiency HVAC systems to better manage their energy environments. These customers will also be placed on our existing residential demand rate, and the study will provide valuable information on a customer's ability to use technology to manage the peak demand and lower their bills.
In addition to generation investments, we're upgrading several IT systems to improve our customer interface, facilitate active operation of our transmission and distribution systems and enable participation in the California ISO - Energy Imbalance Market. These investments along with our advanced meter program, which is fully deployed, are enabling integration of advanced technologies while also allowing us to maintain grid stability.
2016 also represents an important year on the regulatory calendar with the APS rate case set to be filed on June 1. APS submitted the notice of intent to file on January 29, which gives notice to the ACC and stakeholders and outlines the primary topics we will propose in the June rate filing. APS will propose the new rates go into effect July 1, 2017, based on the test year ended December 31, 2015, with certain adjustments.
To help achieve this outcome, we have held a series of stakeholder meetings to provide clarity and transparency with the stakeholders. We're also planning to submit an extensive list of standard discovery questions and responses with the June 1st filing.
Let me outline a few of the central topics from the notice of intent to filing. Residential rate design is an area where we will propose changes to better align costs with prices and incentivize cost-reducing technologies. And we will be proposing universal demand rates as well as shifting our time-of-use periods to later in the day. We will also propose a revenue per customer decoupling mechanism that will be adjusted annually to replace the existing lost fixed-cost recovery mechanism. The decoupling mechanism will be proposed on a trial basis until the next rate case to act as a rate-stabilizing mechanism during the transition period to the new rate structure.
The last item I'll mention is we will request the deferral of costs related to 2 large CapEx projects we're investing in the SCs -- excuse me, SCRs at Four Corners and the first ramping natural gas modernization project at Ocotillo. These investments total over $900 million over the next few years, with in-service dates of 2018 and 2019, respectively.
And in the case of the SCRs, since the timing of installations will be close to the end of this rate case, we'll also propose a step mechanism to reflect the deferred SCR costs, similar to the treatment of the Four Corners acquisition.
The docket on value and cost of distributed generation has testimony due on February 25. There also 4 other electric rate cases in process. UNS Electric is the first in line, with hearings set to begin on March 1 in Tucson. We are an active intervenor in the UNS case since it is an important forum to discuss rate design. The testimony we filed supports the concept of 3-part rate design, which incorporates a fixed service charge, an energy charge and a demand charge. This concept was also proposed and supported by UNS Electric and the ACC staff. Related topics, including methodologies for determining the cost to serve customers with solar and the value of solar, will be a central focus in the value and cost of distributed generation docket.
In closing, we delivered on our commitments in 2015. And we are well-positioned for 2016 in the long-term, with a clear plan and a strong leadership team in place to deliver on the plan.
I'll now turn the call over to Jim.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don. And thank you, everyone, for joining us on the call.This morning, we reported our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. As you can see on Slide 3 of the materials, we had a solid year and ended on a strong note.B
componenttext:
Thank you, Don. And thank you, everyone, for joining us on the call.
This morning, we reported our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. As you can see on Slide 3 of the materials, we had a solid year and ended on a strong note.
Before I review the details of our 2015 results, let me touch on a few highlights from the quarter. For the fourth quarter of 2015, we earned $0.37 per share, compared to $0.05 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014.
Slide 4 outlines the variances which drove the increase in our quarterly earnings per share. Looking at gross margin, higher retail sales, favorable weather and the adjustment mechanism were all positive contributors. Also, as we anticipated, lower operations in maintenance business in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to 2014 improved earnings, largely due to lower planned fossil outages.
Now turning to Slide 5, let's review some of the details of our full year results. We delivered positive results in the top 10 of our guidance range, earning $3.92 per share compared to $3.58 per share in 2014, and earned a consolidated ROE of 9.77%, which was in line with our goal of achieving more the 9.5%.
Gross margin was a positive driver for the year, including favorable year-over-year weather. The adjustment mechanisms were also earnings accretive in 2015, including the lost fixed cost recovery mechanism, transmission and our AZ Sun Program. The Four Corners rate change that went into effect on January 1, 2015, was the largest driver in gross margin. However, keep in mind that the Four Corners rate change was largely offset in D&A.
Power usage by APS customers in 2015 versus 2014 contributed to earnings. Weather normalized, retail kilowatt hour sales, updated effects of energy efficiency, customer behavior and distributed generation were up .07 to 1%, year-over-year.
2015 was our strongest year for retail sales growth since 2008, including 3 on Four Corners, in which combined customer and usage growth outweighed the impacts of energy efficiency and distributed generation.
Operations and maintenance expense was lower in 2015 compared to 2014 due in part to our ongoing cost management efforts. The largest reductions include a decrease in employee benefit costs and lower costs related to fossil plant outages.
Lower interest expense net of AFUDC was another benefit to earnings in 2015 compared to 2014. The decrease included reduce charges resulting from refinancing long-term debt and a lower rate and higher construction in work-in-progress balances, benefiting AFUDC.
Higher depreciation and amortization expense was the primary headwind to 2015 earnings as compared to 2014.
As we reported all year, higher D&A decreased earnings due in part to the absence of the 2014 Four Corners cost deferrals and related 2015 amortization of the deferrals in the costs associated with the Four Corners acquisition in 2013. Additional planting service also reduced year-over-year earnings.
Because Arizona's economy is an integral part of our business story, let me highlight to you the trends we are seeing in our local economy and in particular, the Metro Phoenix area.
By and large, what you see on Slide 6 is the continuation of the consistent growth trends we have been describing for you the last couple of years. Job growth in the fourth quarter in the Metro Phoenix area remained above the national average, as it has for the past 18 quarters. As seen on the upper panel, Metro Phoenix added jobs at a 2.8% year-over-year rate. This job growth is broad-based with the construction, healthcare, tourism, financial, business sectors, consumer services sectors, each adding jobs at a rate above 3%. Notably, the construction sector has been adding jobs in the last 2 quarters at a rate of above 7%. Growth in consumer spending remains robust, and the healthy market continues to strengthen.
Our expectation for the Metro Phoenix housing permits can be seen on the lower panel. In 2015, the housing market recorded it's best year since 2007, from both total permits and the single-family sector by itself, with almost 22,000 permits and 15,000 permits, respectively. This level of single-family permit activity represents an increase over the prior year of almost 50%. As you can see on the slide, we expect the housing market to improve in 2016, with total housing permits within a range of 25,000 to 32,000.
In summary, the Metro Phoenix economy continues to grow steadily and is positioned for stronger growth in the next couple of years.
As I had mentioned before, Arizona and the Metro Phoenix remain attractive places to live and do business, especially as it is situated relative to the high-cost California market. 2015 was better than 2014 in terms of job growth, income growth, consumer spending and new construction, and we expect to see 2016 to be better than 2015.
Reflecting the steady improvement in economic conditions, APS's retain customer base grew 1.3%, compared with the fourth quarter last year and 1.2% year-over-year. We expect that this growth rate will gradually accelerate in response to the economic growth trends I just discussed. Importantly, the long-term fundamentals supporting future population, job growth and economic development in Arizona appear to be in place.
Now, I'll review our earnings guidance and financial outlook.
Last quarter, we issued Pinnacle West consolidated ongoing earnings for 2016, which we continue to expect to be the range of $3.90 to $4.10 per share. The adjusted mechanism, particularly transmission and the LFCR along with modest sales growth and normal weather, remained the key gross margin drivers. O&M is above trend in 2016. However, non-outage O&M spend remains flat. As you may recall, last year we reported that we had moved a planned Four Corners unit outage from 2015 to 2016. 2016 includes major planned outages of both Four Corners and Toya [ph]. The planned 82-day major overhaul at Four Corners Unit 5 started in January, which creates a Q1 2016 earnings headwind of about $0.13 quarter-over-quarter. Keep in mind, this was factored into our guidance.
Overall, our focus remains on our cost management efforts as we look through 2016 and beyond, but the outages are a priority for us this year. One other comment on O&M, the funded status of our pension plan remains strong at 88%, as of year-end 2015. The continued implementation of our liability-driven investment strategy has helped us keep costs down. There is a slide in the appendix with additional details on our pension plan.
You'll find a complete list of factors and assumptions underlying our guidance in the appendix to our slides which are unchanged.
As Don mentioned, our balance sheet remains strong. I will outline our financial plan and how the impact of bonus depreciation has factored in. We already assumed a two-year extension of bonus depreciation that was incorporated to our rate base disclosures in the last earnings call. Our updated estimates can be found in the appendix would show an incremental reduction in rate base of approximately $200 million in 2018 as a result of the bonus depreciation.
However, the extension also resulted in approximately $550 million of total cash benefits to 2019, which provides financing flexibility over that time horizon. In terms of capital expenditures, we anticipate APS's spend to average around $1.2 billion annually from 2016 to 2018, which will be primarily funded through internally generated cash flow. With this capital spending level taking into account the bonus depreciation, we continue to expect our rate base to grow at a average annual rate of 6% to 7% through 2018.
Turning to 2016 financing, we plan to refinance the $250-million maturity in August and anticipate issuance of $400 million of additional long-term debt. Overall, the quarter remains very strong. At the end of 2015, neither Pinnacle West nor APS had any short-term debt outstanding.
In summary, given the strength of our balance sheet coupled with the extension of bonus depreciation, we no longer forecast the need for additional equity. The net effect of bonus depreciation and the removal of equity leaves us relatively neutral from an earnings perspective. We will continue to review our capital forecast to identify additional investment opportunities as we move forward.
This concludes our prepared remarks. I'll now turn the call back over to the operator for questions.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Paul Mountain, Director
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Paul Mountain, Director of Investor Relations. Thank you, sir. You may begin.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christine.I'd like to thank everyone for participating in this conference call and webcast to review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings, recent developments and operating performance.Our speakers today will be our Chairman and C
componenttext:
Thank you, Christine.
I'd like to thank everyone for participating in this conference call and webcast to review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings, recent developments and operating performance.
Our speakers today will be our Chairman and CEO, Don Brandt; and our CFO, Jim Hatfield. Jeff Guldner, APS's Senior Vice President of Public Policy; and Mark Schiavoni, APS's Chief Operating Officer, are also here with us.
First, I need to cover a few details with you. The slides that we will be using are available on our Investor Relations website, along with our earnings release and related information. Note that the slides contain reconciliations of certain non-GAAP financial information.
Today's comments on our slides contain forward-looking statements based on current expectations, and the company assumes no obligation to update these statements. Because actual results may differ materially from expectations, we caution you not to place undue reliance on these statements.
Our 2015 Form 10-K was filed this morning. Please refer to that document for forward-looking statements, cautionary language as well as the risk factors in MD&A sections, which identify risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in our disclosures.
A replay of this call will be available shortly on our website for the next 30 days. It will also be available by telephone through February 26.
I will now turn the call over to Don.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul, and thank you all for joining us today.Pinnacle West delivered a solid 2015 with earnings near the high end of our guidance range with Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station having a record year and with the balance sheet that remains one o
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul, and thank you all for joining us today.
Pinnacle West delivered a solid 2015 with earnings near the high end of our guidance range with Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station having a record year and with the balance sheet that remains one of the strongest in the industry. Jim will discuss the financial results and outlook. My comments will focus mostly on the year ahead.
Our fleet performed very well in 2015, highlighted by Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Stations highest output every, equating to a capacity factor of 94.3%. One of Palo Verde's key strengths is the ability of the team to perform at an excellent level but to also drive continuous improvement in each year.
2016 marks the beginning of a new period for our fleet. In total, we are planning to invest over $3.6 billion in capital over the next 3 years. We're investing in 2 large projects in our fossil fleet, as well as a few innovative investments and some IT systems to prepare our operations for the long term. The 2 large fossil projects are the Ocotillo Modernization Project and the selective catalytic reduction pollution controls, or SCRs as they're called, at the Four Corners generating plant.
Four Corners Unit 5 entered a major outage in January to make several upgrades and begin laying the groundwork for the SCR installations. The innovative investments I will outline are designed to increase customer and system reliability and meet future resource needs. In November, we announced the partnership with the Department of The Navy to develop a 25-megawatt microgrid project at Marine Corps Air Station Yuma. This is APS's first microgrid project, and the first military base to secure 100% backup power.
We also plan to install a 40-megawatt solar facility this year on behalf of some of our larger customers. This amount has been reflected in our 2016 CapEx budget.
The Solar Partner Program, which is planned for 1500 APS-owned rooftop solar installations, is on track to be fully installed and operational by mid-2016. And just this month, we officially launched our solar innovation study, a 75-home demand rate laboratory here in the Metro Phoenix area, which will determine how customers can use various combinations of distributed energy resources such as solar panels, battery storage, smart thermostats and high-efficiency HVAC systems to better manage their energy environments. These customers will also be placed on our existing residential demand rate, and the study will provide valuable information on a customer's ability to use technology to manage the peak demand and lower their bills.
In addition to generation investments, we're upgrading several IT systems to improve our customer interface, facilitate active operation of our transmission and distribution systems and enable participation in the California ISO - Energy Imbalance Market. These investments along with our advanced meter program, which is fully deployed, are enabling integration of advanced technologies while also allowing us to maintain grid stability.
2016 also represents an important year on the regulatory calendar with the APS rate case set to be filed on June 1. APS submitted the notice of intent to file on January 29, which gives notice to the ACC and stakeholders and outlines the primary topics we will propose in the June rate filing. APS will propose the new rates go into effect July 1, 2017, based on the test year ended December 31, 2015, with certain adjustments.
To help achieve this outcome, we have held a series of stakeholder meetings to provide clarity and transparency with the stakeholders. We're also planning to submit an extensive list of standard discovery questions and responses with the June 1st filing.
Let me outline a few of the central topics from the notice of intent to filing. Residential rate design is an area where we will propose changes to better align costs with prices and incentivize cost-reducing technologies. And we will be proposing universal demand rates as well as shifting our time-of-use  periods to later in the day. We will also propose a revenue per customer decoupling mechanism that will be adjusted annually to replace the existing lost fixed-cost recovery mechanism. The decoupling mechanism will be proposed on a trial basis until the next rate case to act as a rate-stabilizing mechanism during the transition period to the new rate structure.
The last item I'll mention is we will request the deferral of costs related to 2 large CapEx projects we're investing in the SCs -- excuse me, SCRs at Four Corners and the first ramping natural gas modernization project at Ocotillo. These investments total over $900 million over the next few years, with in-service dates of 2018 and 2019, respectively.
And in the case of the SCRs, since the timing of installations will be close to the end of this rate case, we'll also propose a step mechanism to reflect the deferred SCR costs, similar to the treatment of the Four Corners acquisition.
The docket on value and cost of distributed generation has testimony due on February 25. There also 4 other electric rate cases in process. UNS Electric is the first in line, with hearings set to begin on March 1 in Tucson. We are an active intervenor in the UNS case since it is an important forum to discuss rate design. The testimony we filed supports the concept of 3-part rate design, which incorporates a fixed service charge, an energy charge and a demand charge. This concept was also proposed and supported by UNS Electric and the ACC staff. Related topics, including methodologies for determining the cost to serve customers with solar and the value of solar, will be a central focus in the value and cost of distributed generation docket.
In closing, we delivered on our commitments in 2015. And we are well-positioned for 2016 in the long-term, with a clear plan and a strong leadership team in place to deliver on the plan.
I'll now turn the call over to Jim.

headline: Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don. And thank you, everyone, for joining us on the call.This morning, we reported our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. As you can see on Slide 3 of the materials, we had a solid year and ended on a strong note.B
componenttext:
Thank you, Don. And thank you, everyone, for joining us on the call.
This morning, we reported our financial results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015. As you can see on Slide 3 of the materials, we had a solid year and ended on a strong note.
Before I review the details of our 2015 results, let me touch on a few highlights from the quarter. For the fourth quarter of 2015, we earned $0.37 per share, compared to $0.05 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014.
Slide 4 outlines the variances which drove the increase in our quarterly earnings per share. Looking at gross margin, higher retail sales, favorable weather and the adjustment mechanism were all positive contributors. Also, as we anticipated, lower operations in maintenance business in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to 2014 improved earnings, largely due to lower planned fossil outages.
Now turning to Slide 5, let's review some of the details of our full year results. We delivered positive results in the top 10 of our guidance range, earning $3.92 per share compared to $3.58 per share in 2014, and earned a consolidated ROE of 9.77%, which was in line with our goal of achieving more the 9.5%.
Gross margin was a positive driver for the year, including favorable year-over-year weather. The adjustment mechanisms were also earnings accretive in 2015, including the lost fixed cost recovery mechanism, transmission and our AZ Sun Program. The Four Corners rate change that went into effect on January 1, 2015, was the largest driver in gross margin. However, keep in mind that the Four Corners rate change was largely offset in D&A.
Power usage by APS customers in 2015 versus 2014 contributed to earnings. Weather normalized, retail kilowatt hour sales, updated effects of energy efficiency, customer behavior and distributed generation were up 0.7% to 1%, year-over-year.
2015 was our strongest year for retail sales growth since 2008, including 3 on Four Corners, in which combined customer and usage growth outweighed the impacts of energy efficiency and distributed generation.
Operations and maintenance expense was lower in 2015 compared to 2014 due in part to our ongoing cost management efforts. The largest reductions include a decrease in employee benefit costs and lower costs related to fossil plant outages.
Lower interest expense net of AFUDC was another benefit to earnings in 2015 compared to 2014. The decrease included reduce charges resulting from refinancing long-term debt and a lower rate and higher construction in work-in-progress balances, benefiting AFUDC.
Higher depreciation and amortization expense was the primary headwind to 2015 earnings as compared to 2014.
As we reported all year, higher D&A decreased earnings due in part to the absence of the 2014 Four Corners cost deferrals and related 2015 amortization of the deferrals in the costs associated with the Four Corners acquisition in 2013. Additional planting service also reduced year-over-year earnings.
Because Arizona's economy is  an integral part of our business story, let me highlight to you the trends we are seeing in our local economy and in particular, the Metro Phoenix area.
By and large, what you see on Slide 6 is the continuation of the consistent growth trends we have been describing for you the last couple of years. Job growth in the fourth quarter in the Metro Phoenix area remained above the national average as it has for the past 18 quarters. As seen on the upper panel, Metro Phoenix added jobs at a 2.8% year-over-year rate. This job growth is broad-based with the construction, healthcare, tourism, financial, business sectors, consumer services sectors, each adding jobs at a rate above 3%. Notably, the construction sector has been adding jobs in the last 2 quarters at a rate of above 7%. Growth in consumer spending remains robust, and the healthy market continues to strengthen.
Our expectation for the Metro Phoenix housing permits can be seen on the lower panel. In 2015, the housing market recorded its best year since 2007, from both total permits and the single-family sector by itself, with almost 22,000 permits and 15,000 permits, respectively. This level of single-family permit activity represents an increase over the prior year of almost 50%. As you can see on the slide, we expect the housing market to improve in 2016, with total housing permits within a range of 25,000 to 32,000.
In summary, the Metro Phoenix economy continues to grow steadily and is positioned for stronger growth in the next couple of years.
As I had mentioned before, Arizona and the Metro Phoenix remain attractive places to live and do business, especially as it is situated relative to the high-cost California market. 2015 was better than 2014 in terms of job growth, income growth, consumer spending and new construction, and we expect to see 2016 to be better than 2015.
Reflecting the steady improvement in economic conditions, APS's retain customer base grew 1.3%, compared with the fourth quarter last year and 1.2% year-over-year. We expect that this growth rate will gradually accelerate in response to the economic growth trends I just discussed. Importantly, the long-term fundamentals supporting future population, job growth and economic development in Arizona appear to be in place.
Now, I'll review our earnings guidance and financial outlook.
Last quarter, we issued Pinnacle West consolidated ongoing earnings for 2016, which we continue to expect to be the range of $3.90 to $4.10 per share. The adjusted mechanism, particularly transmission and the LFCR along with modest sales growth and normal weather, remained the key gross margin drivers. O&M is above trend in 2016. However, non-outage O&M spend remains flat. As you may recall, last year we reported that we had moved a planned Four Corners unit outage from 2015 to 2016. 2016 includes major planned outages of both Four Corners and Cholla. The planned 82-day major overhaul at Four Corners Unit 5 started in January, which creates a Q1 2016 earnings headwind of about $0.13 quarter-over-quarter. Keep in mind, this was factored into our guidance.
 Overall, our focus remains on our cost management efforts as we look through 2016 and beyond, but the outages are a priority for us this year. One other comment on O&M, the funded status of our pension plan remains strong at 88%, as of year-end 2015. The continued implementation of our liability-driven investment strategy has helped us keep costs down. There is a slide in the appendix with additional details on our pension plan.
You'll find a complete list of factors and assumptions underlying our guidance in the appendix to our slides which are unchanged.
As Don mentioned, our balance sheet remains strong. I will outline our financial plan and how the impact of bonus depreciation has factored in. We  already assumed a two-year extension of bonus depreciation that was incorporated to our rate base disclosures in the last earnings call. Our updated estimates can be found in the appendix would show an incremental reduction in rate base of approximately $200 million in 2018 as a result of the bonus depreciation.
However, the extension also resulted in approximately $550 million of total cash benefits to 2019, which provides financing flexibility over that time horizon. In terms of capital expenditures, we anticipate APS's spend to average around $1.2 billion annually from 2016 to 2018, which will be primarily funded through internally generated cash flow. With this capital spending level taking into account the bonus depreciation, we continue to expect our rate base to grow at an average annual rate of 6% to 7% through 2018.
  Turning to 2016 financing, we plan to refinance the $250-million maturity in August and anticipate issuance of $400 million of additional long-term debt. Overall, the quarter remains very strong. At the end of 2015, neither Pinnacle West nor APS had any short-term debt outstanding.
In summary, given the strength of our balance sheet coupled with the extension of bonus depreciation, we no longer forecast the need for additional equity. The net effect of bonus depreciation and the removal of equity leaves us relatively neutral from an earnings perspective. We will continue to review our capital forecast to identify additional investment opportunities as we move forward.
This concludes our prepared remarks. I'll now turn the call back over to the operator for questions.

componenttext: We've made a fair number of changes earlier last, probably 2 or 3 rate cases that have picked that up. A lot of it comes in the time to process the case and trying to get that processing time down to about a year or so, and things we've done with that are, for example, prefiling the discovery. So we don't wait -- file the case, wait for 3 or 4 months and then begin the discovery process. And so a lot of that's been worked out. Obviously, adjustor mechanisms and how you can work on adjustment mechanisms can help smooth that even further. And so that's probably going to be some of the discussion you'll see, and that's part of what we've been talking about with stakeholders.
